channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: 'Like Armageddon': Rotting food, dead animals and chaos at postal facilities amid cutbacks
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson, Maya Lau
item.description: Accounts from employees at California postal facilities provide a glimpse of the chaos amid both the pandemic and widespread cuts imposed by the USPS.
item.content:encoded: Accounts from employees at California postal facilities provide a glimpse of the chaos amid both the pandemic and widespread cuts imposed by the USPS.

media:content.media:description: Postal workers sort parcels at Margaret L. Sellers Processing and Distribution Center at the USPS Carmel Mountain Post Office on May 14, 2020 in San Diego, California. The post office is seeing a huge increase in the amount of packages its handling.
media:content.media:credit: Eduardo Contreras/Eduardo Contreras/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Orange County reports its first coronavirus-related death of a child
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: The teenage girl, whose age and identity were not released, had underlying medical conditions, the county's health department said.
item.content:encoded: The teenage girl, whose age and identity were not released, had underlying medical conditions, the county's health department said.

media:content.media:description: The coronavirus known as SARS-CoV-2, shown in purple, infects a cell, colored in green.
media:content.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

item.title: COVID-19 outbreak at Folsom Prison spreads through 10% of inmates in 2 weeks
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: A total of 233 inmates have tested positive for COVID-19 — 226 in roughly the past two weeks — giving Folson the largest outbreak in the state's prison system.
item.content:encoded: A total of 233 inmates have tested positive for COVID-19 — 226 in roughly the past two weeks — giving Folson the largest outbreak in the state's prison system.

media:content.media:description: California's prison system has regained control over inmate healthcare at Folsom State Prison. The state's remaining 33 prisons continue to be controlled by a court-appointed federal overseer.

item.title: PG&E worker dies while helping with Northern California wildfire response
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Pacific Gas & Electric employee was assisting fire crews when he was found unresponsive in his vehicle Wednesday near Vacaville, Cal Fire officials said.
item.content:encoded: The Pacific Gas & Electric employee was assisting fire crews when he was found unresponsive in his vehicle Wednesday near Vacaville, Cal Fire officials said.

media:content.media:description: VACAVILLE, CA - AUGUST 19: Firefighters battle fires along Lyon road during the Hennessy Fire on Wednesday, Aug. 19, 2020 in Vacaville, CA. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Air quality hits danger zone in Bay Area as thick smoke, ash blanket the region
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: San Francisco Bay Area air quality is hazardous. Much of the ground is covered in ash distributed by gusty winds, adding to pollution already clouding the vicinity.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco Bay Area air quality is hazardous. Much of the ground is covered in ash distributed by gusty winds, adding to pollution already clouding the vicinity.

media:content.media:description: The San Francisco skyline is obscured by smoke from wildfires, as the Golden Gate Bridge rises in the foreground Wednesday, Aug. 19, 2020, in this view from the Marin Headlands near Sausalito, Calif. Crews were battling wildfires in the San Francisco Bay Area and thousands of people were under orders to evacuate Wednesday as hundreds of wildfires blazed across the state amid a blistering heat wave now in its second week. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: Education is a top U.S. priority, and there's wide support for online learning, poll finds
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: A majority of respondents said they opposed reopening K-12 schools for in-person instruction in fall 2020 amid the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: A majority of respondents said they opposed reopening K-12 schools for in-person instruction in fall 2020 amid the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: WALNUT PARK, CA - AUGUST 13: Academia Moderna in Walnut Park, will reopen with a staggered schedule and smaller class sizes with increased distancing. Photographed at Academia Moderna on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2020 in Walnut Park, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Catastrophe' or 'new era'? Mail shake-up at L.A. public housing complex alarms residents
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Mail would no longer be delivered to residents' doors at Mar Vista Gardens under a new plan. Officials say it would keep letter carriers safer, but residents are skeptical.
item.content:encoded: Mail would no longer be delivered to residents' doors at Mar Vista Gardens under a new plan. Officials say it would keep letter carriers safer, but residents are skeptical.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 18: Daisy Vega, president of the resident advisory council at the Mar Vista Gardens public housing complex, poses for a portrait in front of her apartment in Mar Vista Gardens on Tuesday, Aug. 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. She is worried about a possible change in mail delivery that would stop bringing letters to residents' doors, instead bringing them to centralized banks of mailboxes in the complex. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Bay Area firestorms send thousands fleeing and cause dangerous air quality
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust, Anita Chabria, Rong-Gong Lin II, Joseph Serna
item.description: Many San Francisco Bay Area residents say they've never seen such wildfire conditions, a product of high temperatures, strong winds and thousands of lightning strikes.
item.content:encoded: Many San Francisco Bay Area residents say they've never seen such wildfire conditions, a product of high temperatures, strong winds and thousands of lightning strikes.

media:content.media:description: Matt Nichols sprays water while trying to save his home as the LNU Lightning Complex fires tear through Vacaville, Calif., on Wednesday, Aug. 19, 2020. Fire crews across the region scrambled to contain dozens of wildfires sparked by lightning strikes as a statewide heat wave continues. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: Computer glitches, pleas for patience, worried parents and giddy kids mark back to school
item.dc:creator: Paloma Esquivel, Howard Blume, Andrew J. Campa, Cindy Carcamo
item.description: LAUSD students head back to school this week and the first days offer a look at the challenges ahead: computer glitches, worried parents and anxious students and teachers.
item.content:encoded: LAUSD students head back to school this week and the first days offer a look at the challenges ahead: computer glitches, worried parents and anxious students and teachers.

media:content.media:description: NORTHRIDGE, CA - AUGUST 18: Oliver Wendell Holmes Middle School principal Kim D'Aloisio hosts for a virtual meeting with staff socially distanced in the school auditorium to mark the beginning of the school year Tuesday, Aug. 18, 2020 in Northridge, CA. Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Monster fires in Bay Area threaten dozens of communities as thousands flee
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money, Leila Miller, Joseph Serna
item.description: Fires raging in Northern and Central California are forcing thousands from their homes and turning the air into an increasing health hazard.
item.content:encoded: Fires raging in Northern and Central California are forcing thousands from their homes and turning the air into an increasing health hazard.

media:content.media:description: Burned vehicles rest beneath a tree after the LNU Lightning Complex fires tore through Vacaville, Calif., on Wednesday, Aug. 19, 2020. Fire crews across the region scrambled to contain dozens of wildfires sparked by lightning strikes as a statewide heat wave continues. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: Skelton: Don't pay any attention to Trump. Voting by mail in California is safe, secure and reliable
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: "Voters should be able to cast their ballots in the safest way possible," Democratic Secretary of State Alex Padilla said. "The safest bet is to vote by mail."
item.content:encoded: "Voters should be able to cast their ballots in the safest way possible," Democratic Secretary of State Alex Padilla said. "The safest bet is to vote by mail."

media:content.media:description: Schaben, Allen J.  B58838709Z.1 NORWALK, CA NOVEMBER 4, 2010: Nancy Fulton, a clerk, sorts vote by mail ballots in preparation for Friday's vote tally at the Los Angeles County Registrar's office in Norwalk. The race for California Attorney General will come down to a tally of vote by mail votes as Kamala Harris leads Steve Cooley by a slim margin. ( Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times )
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. County Supervisor Solis, Mayor Garcetti press for economic recovery at Democratic convention
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: The two local officials sought to bolster Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden's image as someone who can bring back jobs erased by the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: The two local officials sought to bolster Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden's image as someone who can bring back jobs erased by the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: Genaro Molina Los Angeles Times SUPERVISOR

item.title: "I'm dying right here": Injured L.A. firefighters recount narrow escape from downtown blast
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Months after a blast severely injured 11 firefighters in downtown L.A., several first responders spoke out about the near-death experience
item.content:encoded: Months after a blast severely injured 11 firefighters in downtown L.A., several first responders spoke out about the near-death experience

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA AUGUST 19, 2020-L.A. City Firefighter Andrew Tom, who has burns to his waist and legs, greets L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti at a reunion for injured firefighters at the Grossman Burn Center in West Hills Wednesday. The firefighters were caught in a ball of fire after an explosion at a buisness in Downtown Los Angeles in May. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. Mayor Garcetti orders power shut off at TikTok influencer house
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti ordered the power cut at a swanky Hollywood Hills residence that police say held parties in violation of public health orders and is the home of several TikTok stars, including Bryce Hall.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti ordered the power cut at a swanky Hollywood Hills residence that police say held parties in violation of public health orders and is the home of several TikTok stars, including Bryce Hall.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA - AUGUST 11: Giovanny Valencia (R) and Bryce Hall attends Beautycon Festival Los Angeles 2019 at Los Angeles Convention Center on August 11, 2019 in Los Angeles, California. (Photo by Araya Diaz/Getty Images for Beautycon)

item.title: California is asking Trump administration for new $300-a-week jobless benefit
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said Wednesday he plans to apply to the federal government for a $300 weekly supplemental unemployment benefit for jobless Californians.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom said Wednesday he plans to apply to the federal government for a $300 weekly supplemental unemployment benefit for jobless Californians.

media:content.media:description: A job seeker waits to use a phone at a career center in Richmond, Calif. Economist Jack Kyser predicts that the state's jobless rate will average 12.6% next year, but other economists call his prediction overly pessimistic.

item.title: Firefighting helicopter crash kills pilot, sparks 50-acre fire in Fresno County
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna
item.description: A firefighting helicopter crashed in Fresno County on Wednesday, killing the pilot and briefly sparking another brush fire to join the dozens burning across the state.
item.content:encoded: A firefighting helicopter crashed in Fresno County on Wednesday, killing the pilot and briefly sparking another brush fire to join the dozens burning across the state.

item.title: L.A. County finally seeing declines in Latino, Black coronavirus mortality rates
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Health officials note an overall drop in death rates across all demographics and a "narrowing of the gap" among coronavirus victims of varying racial, ethnic and socioeconomic backgrounds.
item.content:encoded: Health officials note an overall drop in death rates across all demographics and a "narrowing of the gap" among coronavirus victims of varying racial, ethnic and socioeconomic backgrounds.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA - AUGUST 18, 2020 - - Nurse Richelle Legaspi, a member of the outreach team with The Center, finishes giving John Yu, who is homeless, a COVID-19 test while outreach worker Douglas Walker, left, looks on in East Hollywood on August 18,, 2020. Members of the outreach team with The Center have been helping the homeless who have been dealing with the coronavirus pandemic and deliver food and water during the heat wave. The Center is a non-profit organization that has been helping the homeless community in Hollywood for many years. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Britney Spears' conservatorship hearing is sealed from public again
item.dc:creator: Nardine Saad
item.description: As singer Britney Spears tries to oust her father as her sole conservator, a judge granted a motion to seal a hearing and transcripts in her case Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: As singer Britney Spears tries to oust her father as her sole conservator, a judge granted a motion to seal a hearing and transcripts in her case Wednesday.

media:content.media:description: Britney Spears at the 2011 Billboard Music Awards in Las Vegas.

item.title: 'No one is ready for it.' Fleeing a raging fire amid the coronavirus pandemic
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Hundreds of families fled their homes in Vacaville on Wednesday. Some went to shelters, worried both about the flames and the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of families fled their homes in Vacaville on Wednesday. Some went to shelters, worried both about the flames and the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: VACAVILLE, CA - AUGUST 19: Kaiser Permanente Nurses Jenn Ellis, Blanca Ramirez, and Bindi Miller walk the parking lot of the Vacaville Community Center checking on people who were displaced by the Hennessy Fire on Wednesday, Aug. 19, 2020 in Vacaville, CA. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: D.A. reviewing possible charges in Megan Thee Stallion shooting case
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The L.A. County district attorney's office asks the LAPD to further investigate an incident in which rapper Megan Thee Stallion claims she was shot.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. County district attorney's office asks the LAPD to further investigate an incident in which rapper Megan Thee Stallion claims she was shot.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Aug. 26, 2019 file photo, Megan Thee Stallion arrives at the MTV Video Music Awards in Newark, N.J.. The rapper says she was shot multiple times, but expects to fully recover. The 25-year-old said in an Instagram post Wednesday that she had gunshot wounds from a crime committed against her Sunday with the intent to harm her and feels lucky to be alive. She did not say who shot her or why, and Los Angeles police had no immediate comment. (Photo by Charles Sykes/Invision/AP, File)

item.title: California firefighting resources 'stretched' by 23 major wildfires, Newsom says
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: California is struggling to battle 23 major wildfires in what has become an acute fire season in the state.
item.content:encoded: California is struggling to battle 23 major wildfires in what has become an acute fire season in the state.

media:content.media:description: Flames consume a cabin at the Nichelini Family Winery in unincorporated Napa County as the Hennessey Fire burns on Tuesday, Aug. 18, 2020. A winery family member said they had spent 10 hours Monday rebuilding the cabin's foundation. Fire crews across the region scrambled to contain dozens of blazes sparked by lightning strikes as a statewide heat wave continues. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: Golden State Killer's ex-fiancee joins long line of victims confronting him in court

item.title: How key bottlenecks scrambled COVID-19 testing in Sacramento

item.description: Sacramento has been plagued by bottlenecks in its COVID-19 testing system that have reduced capacity and slowed results, especially during the summer surge.
item.content:encoded: Sacramento has been plagued by bottlenecks in its COVID-19 testing system that have reduced capacity and slowed results, especially during the summer surge.

item.title: Smoke from wildfires chokes Bay Area as ozone smog threatens Southern California
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Particulate pollution is rife in the San Francisco Bay Area following numerous lightning-sparked fires. Intense heat is triggering ozone smog alerts elsewhere.

item.title: Hate crime investigation underway after transgender women robbed, beaten in Hollywood
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Los Angeles police launch a hate crime investigation after three women were assaulted and robbed about 2:15 a.m. Monday on Hollywood Boulevard.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles police launch a hate crime investigation after three women were assaulted and robbed about 2:15 a.m. Monday on Hollywood Boulevard.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 14: A man crosses Hollywood Boulevard in Hollywood on Friday, Aug. 14, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Temperatures for the upcoming weekend in Los Angeles are to be in the upper 90s. (Josie Norris / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Destructive Bay Area fires fueled by rare mix of intense dry lightning and extreme heat
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna, Rong-Gong Lin II, Leila Miller
item.description: Destructive Bay Area fires have been fueled by an unusual combination of dry lightning and extreme heat.
item.content:encoded: Destructive Bay Area fires have been fueled by an unusual combination of dry lightning and extreme heat.

media:content.media:description: A rare lightning storm crackles over Mitchell's Cove in Santa Cruz, California around 3 a.m. Sunday morning August 16, 2020. The severe storm system rolled through the San Francisco and Monterey Bay areas early Sunday, packing a combination of dry lightning and high winds that triggered wildfires throughout the region. The National Weather Service on Sunday extended a red flag fire warning for the entire Bay Area until 11 a.m. Monday morning. (Shmuel Thaler/The Santa Cruz Sentinel via AP)

item.title: Have you noticed any problems with the U.S. Postal Service in your area?

item.title: In searing heat, with a pandemic raging, homeless workers are on a quest to save lives in Hollywood
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: L.A.'s growing population of homeless people had enough troubles. They didn't need the coronavirus on top of them — or this wretched, blistering heat wave.
item.content:encoded: L.A.'s growing population of homeless people had enough troubles. They didn't need the coronavirus on top of them — or this wretched, blistering heat wave.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA - AUGUST 18, 2020 - - Nurse Richelle Legaspi, a member of the outreach team with The Center, helps bandage a wound Pookie Moore's leg in East Hollywood on August 18,, 2020. Moore has been living homeless for the past two years. Members of the outreach team with The Center have been helping the homeless who have been dealing with the coronavirus pandemic and deliver food and water during the heat wave. The Center is a non-profit organization that has been helping the homeless community in Hollywood for many years. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA - AUGUST 18, 2020: Jon Galapago of Riverside wipes the sweat from his face while sitting in a hammock fishing at Lake Evans in triple digit temperatures on August 18, 2020 in Riverside, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Gimme Shelter': California's looming 'eviction cliff' could lead to millions losing their homes
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon
item.description: On Sept. 1, California's courts will begin processing eviction and foreclosure cases again. With a federal deal far from certain, all eyes are on Gov. Gavin Newsom and the state Legislature to come up with a fix.
item.content:encoded: On Sept. 1, California's courts will begin processing eviction and foreclosure cases again. With a federal deal far from certain, all eyes are on Gov. Gavin Newsom and the state Legislature to come up with a fix.

media:content.media:description: Rep. Maxine Waters (D-Los Angeles) speaks during a House committee meeting in Washington on Sept. 8.

item.title: When the pandemic hit, 26 new city homeless shelters opened. Only seven are left
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes, Gale Holland
item.description: At the peak 26 parks and recreation centers in Los Angeles were being used as homeless shelters. Now there are seven.
item.content:encoded: At the peak 26 parks and recreation centers in Los Angeles were being used as homeless shelters. Now there are seven.

media:content.media:description: WESTWOOD, CALIF. -- FRIDAY, MARCH 20, 2020: LA City parks and recreation staffer Chris Smith along with volunteers from the Salvation Army set up cots for homeless at Westwood Recreation Center in Westwood, Calif., on March 20, 2020. Officials hope to get the center open by 3 pm today, with cots set up 6 feet apart in separate areas for men and women. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 'Why is this happening to us?': Coronavirus takes a toll on Latinos and funeral homes
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives
item.description: The pandemic has had a disproportionate impact on Latinos — and on the mortuaries that help families say goodbye to their loved ones
item.content:encoded: The pandemic has had a disproportionate impact on Latinos — and on the mortuaries that help families say goodbye to their loved ones

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, August 4, 2020 - Felipe Juarez, a victim of Covid-19, is memorialized at Continental's first outdoor service in compliance of a State and City mandates preventing indoor gatherings. In the throes of the Covid-19 epidemic Continental Funeral Home struggles to keep up with the demands of rising death rates in a community suffering with health and finances. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Reopening elementary schools is risky — but so is keeping them closed
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Experts say it's going to be a tough call for figuring out how to get elementary schools reopened. Reopening elementary schools when disease transmission is too high is risky.
item.content:encoded: Experts say it's going to be a tough call for figuring out how to get elementary schools reopened. Reopening elementary schools when disease transmission is too high is risky.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 18: Tunette Powell, 34, rests her hand on her son Joah Powell's, 9, head as they wait to pick up school supplies during the first day of school at Baldwin Hills Elementary School on Tuesday, Aug. 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Josie Norris / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Cold-blooded or reformed? Clemency for a killer reopens a family's wounds
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: Forty years after a man was sentenced to life in prison for murdering his wife, he's been given a chance at freedom. The woman's family is shocked.
item.content:encoded: Forty years after a man was sentenced to life in prison for murdering his wife, he's been given a chance at freedom. The woman's family is shocked.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA -JULY 23, 2020: Debbie Bailey's family members from left to right-her brother-in law-Dave Goldsworhy, her sister and Dave's wife, Kathy Goldsworthy, her niece and Dave and Kathy's daughter Patricia Goldsworthy-Bishop, and her brother Jeff Bailey visit her gravesite, right, and her parents gravesite, Pauline and Robert Bailey, center, at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Glendale. Debbie was cold-bloodedly murdered in 1980 by her husband Thomas Waterbury who has been in prison since. He was recently commuted by Gov. Gavin Newsom, though the family was not notified of his commutation or allowed to comment on the case (as they should have been.) (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Firestorm in Bay Area grows quickly to 124,000 acres, now threatening 25,000 structures
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Luke Money, Anita Chabria, Joseph Serna, Taryn Luna, Susanne Rust, Leila Miller
item.description: The LNU Lightning Complex fire has burned more than 124,000 acres in Napa, Sonoma, Solano, Yolo and Lake counties. Evacuations have been ordered in western Vacaville.
item.content:encoded: The LNU Lightning Complex fire has burned more than 124,000 acres in Napa, Sonoma, Solano, Yolo and Lake counties. Evacuations have been ordered in western Vacaville.

media:content.media:description: Burned vehicles rest beneath a tree after the LNU Lightning Complex fires tore through Vacaville, Calif., on Wednesday, Aug. 19, 2020. Fire crews across the region scrambled to contain dozens of wildfires sparked by lightning strikes as a statewide heat wave continues. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: Op-Ed: Warren Buffett can save the Klamath River Basin. Will he?
item.dc:creator: Jacques Leslie
item.description: The removal of four dams along the California-Oregon border is crucial to the Yurok and Karuk tribes, the Klamath's salmon runs and the river itself.
item.content:encoded: The removal of four dams along the California-Oregon border is crucial to the Yurok and Karuk tribes, the Klamath's salmon runs and the river itself.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Aug. 21, 2009 file photo, water trickles over Copco 1 Dam on the Klamath River outside Hornbrook, Calif. The process to relicense the hydroelectric dam system on the Klamath River has restarted again as historic settlement agreements to remove four of the dams have thus far failed to make headway in Congress this year. The Klamath River basin, which straddles Oregon and California, has long been the site of intense political fights over the sharing of scarce water between farms and fish. The agreements to remove the dams, hammered out by farmers, tribes, environmentalists and states, are a compromise aimed to restore the river for imperiled salmon and steelhead, and give farmers greater certainty about irrigation water. (AP Photo/Jeff Barnard, File)

item.title: Slowing COVID-19 outbreak has California weighing what next reopening will look like
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna
item.description: Although Los Angeles County has met most of the state's benchmarks to allow further reopenings, the average number of infections is still too high.
item.content:encoded: Although Los Angeles County has met most of the state's benchmarks to allow further reopenings, the average number of infections is still too high.

media:content.media:description: People visit a beach in front of the Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk during the coronavirus outbreak in Santa Cruz, Calif., Thursday, July 2, 2020. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)

Attention Editor: That is the dog's name. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Britney Spears 'strongly opposed' to her father being sole conservator

The contract was opposed by some neighborhood activists who argued that it was rushed through without enough scrutiny. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Isolation, confusion: What the COVID-19 pandemic is like for people with dementia
item.dc:creator: Heidi de Marco
item.description: Changes wrought by the COVID-19 pandemic have upended the lives of millions of dementia patients and their caregivers, who rely on long-standing routines.
item.content:encoded: Changes wrought by the COVID-19 pandemic have upended the lives of millions of dementia patients and their caregivers, who rely on long-standing routines.

media:content.media:description: Daisy Conant hasn't been diagnosed with dementia, but she has a family history of Alzheimer's and exhibits clear signs of memory loss. She gets frustrated reading news about the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: California to join legal challenge against Trump administration over USPS reductions
item.dc:creator: Maya Lau
item.description: The move comes as the postmaster general backs off changes for now. California's attorney general calls the changes an attack on a fair election.
item.content:encoded: The move comes as the postmaster general backs off changes for now. California's attorney general calls the changes an attack on a fair election.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Dec. 4, 2019, file photo, California Attorney General Xavier Becerra talk during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif. Attorneys general in 20 states and the District of Columbia sued the Trump administration on Tuesday, July 21, 2020, alleging that new federal rules undermine their ability to protect rivers, lakes and streams within their borders. "The Trump administration wants to clear the deck for fossil fuel infrastructure," Becerra alleged in announcing the legal action, the latest of dozens he has filed against the administration. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli,File)

item.title: Grace Montañez Davis, former L.A. deputy mayor and Eastside political activist, dies at 93
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda, Gustavo Arellano
item.description: Grace Montañez Davis, who served as deputy mayor for Tom Bradley and was the highest ranking woman and Latina during his administration, was 93.
item.content:encoded: Grace Montañez Davis, who served as deputy mayor for Tom Bradley and was the highest ranking woman and Latina during his administration, was 93.

media:content.media:description: Grace Montañez Davis served as deputy mayor for Tom Bradley from 1975 until 1990.

item.title: For second day in a row, rolling blackouts across California are averted
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Alex Wigglesworth, Sammy Roth
item.description: State officials are continuing to urge conservation in an effort to reduce the need for power outages as the state's heat wave peaks.
item.content:encoded: State officials are continuing to urge conservation in an effort to reduce the need for power outages as the state's heat wave peaks.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA - AUGUST 18, 2020: Jon Galapago of Riverside wipes the sweat from his face while sitting in a hammock fishing at Lake Evans in triple digit temperatures on August 18, 2020 in Riverside, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Does L.A. count its homeless, or make its best guess? A little of both, it turns out
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: Keeping track of the number of people who are homeless in Los Angeles is an exercise in uncertainty. Not only do the numbers change from year to year, presumably reflecting real shifts in the homeless population, but, once published, they can still change months or years later — based on changes in how the numbers are calculated.
item.content:encoded: Keeping track of the number of people who are homeless in Los Angeles is an exercise in uncertainty. Not only do the numbers change from year to year, presumably reflecting real shifts in the homeless population, but, once published, they can still change months or years later — based on changes in how the numbers are calculated.

media:content.media:description: NORTH HOLLYWOOD, CA - JANUARY 21, 2020 - Gospel musician Clemmie Williams, 34, lives homeless in North Hollywood Park on January 21, 2020. Williams has been working on part time jobs but it's not enough to make first and last for an apartment he says. "It's a struggle to get back to normalcy," Williams said. Williams was photographed on the first night of the 2020 LA County homeless count. On Tuesday, volunteers with the focused on the San Gabriel and San Fernando valleys. Other swaths of the region, such as the South Bay and Antelope Valley, will be covered Wednesday and Thursday.. The homeless count is overseen by the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority (LAHSA) The volunteers will canvas more than 80 cities and 200 communities across L.A. County over three days to count the number of homeless people living on the streets, according to the LAHSA. Last year's count found that nearly 59,000 people were experiencing homelessness countywide, an increase of 12% from 2018. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Victims of Golden State Killer finally confront him in court with stories of pain and survival
item.dc:creator: Paige St. John, Luke Money
item.description: Victims of Joseph James DeAngelo Jr. will spend three days telling the court about the impact of his crimes before he is sentenced Friday.
item.content:encoded: Victims of Joseph James DeAngelo Jr. will spend three days telling the court about the impact of his crimes before he is sentenced Friday.

media:content.media:description: The victims of Joseph James DeAngelo Jr., the former police officer whose violent crimes through the 1970s and 1980s terrorized Californians across the state and earned him the moniker Golden State Killer, finally get their say in court beginning Tuesday, August 18, 2020.

item.title: L.A. County issues strict rules for colleges reopening during coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe, Nina Agrawal
item.description: After months of waiting, L.A. County colleges received public health rules for fall reopenings: virtually no in-person classes and very limited on-campus housing.
item.content:encoded: After months of waiting, L.A. County colleges received public health rules for fall reopenings: virtually no in-person classes and very limited on-campus housing.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 17, 2020 - - USC student Mitchell Steimle, 21, from left, and his brother Anthony, 18, participate in a wellness check conducted by Campus Health and Screening Ambassadors Sonya Melendez-Fitzgerald, 54, and Ethan Perreira, 21, right, on the first day of academic instruction at USC for the Fall 2020 semester in Los Angeles on August 17, 2020. All students who visit the campus have to go through a wellness check, answer questions regarding COVID-19 symptoms and have their temperature checked before they are allowed to enter campus. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: From 'firenadoes' to record heat, California extreme weather a glimpse of future
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza, Louis Sahagun, Joseph Serna
item.description: As one of the worst heat waves in years continues to broil California, millions are experiencing the havoc that ensues with the type of extreme weather that is growing more frequent with climate change.
item.content:encoded: As one of the worst heat waves in years continues to broil California, millions are experiencing the havoc that ensues with the type of extreme weather that is growing more frequent with climate change.

media:content.media:description: Lightning forks over the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge as a storm passes over Oakland, Calif., Sunday, Aug. 16, 2020. Numerous lightning strikes early Sunday sparked brush fires throughout the region. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: 'Are we ready?' LAUSD's first day back to school, online and on Zoom, is anything but normal
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Paloma Esquivel, Andrew J. Campa
item.description: The L.A. Unified School District opens online Tuesday. But the typical excitement is tempered by families' anxiety and confusion as educators try to offer a 'normal' school day that is anything but amid the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. Unified School District opens online Tuesday. But the typical excitement is tempered by families' anxiety and confusion as educators try to offer a 'normal' school day that is anything but amid the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: WALNUT PARK, CA - AUGUST 13: Xavier Reyes, founder of Alta Public Schools, shows the reduced size and increased spacing in classrooms at Academia Moderna in Walnut Park. The school will reopen with a staggered schedule and smaller class sizes. Photographed at Academia Moderna on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2020 in Walnut Park, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Police reform advocates scrutinize police unions, calling them obstacles to reform
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Police reform advocates who for years have searched for roadblocks to accountability have zeroed in on a new target: police unions.
item.content:encoded: Police reform advocates who for years have searched for roadblocks to accountability have zeroed in on a new target: police unions.

media:content.media:description: FILE â In this March 26, 2016, file photo, Black Lives Matter activist DeRay Mckesson, chatting with campaign volunteers in Baltimore. A federal lawsuit accuses Black Lives Matter and several movement leaders of inciting violence that led to a gunman's deadly ambush of law enforcement officers in Baton Rouge last summer. Mckesson and four other Black Lives Matter leaders are named as defendants in the suit filed Friday on behalf of one of the officers wounded in the July 17 attack by a black military veteran, who killed three other officers before he was shot dead. (AP Photo/Patrick Semansky, File)

item.title: Overruling Cal State trustees, Newsom approves new ethnic studies requirement

item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom signed legislation that makes ethnic studies a graduation requirement across the California State University's 23 campuses.

item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom said San Diego County, the state's second largest, could be taken off the watchlist this week.

The event, on the first day of school, was a partnership between Councilwoman Monica Rodriguez and L.A. Family Housing providing students with backpacks full of school supplies and other essential items for the family. The families participating are those facing economic hardship because of the pandemic. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's top court caps penalties on nursing homes to $500 for certain lawsuits
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Ruling on a 1982 law, the California Supreme Court has limited damages against nursing homes to $500 per lawsuit, a victory for the industry amid the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: Ruling on a 1982 law, the California Supreme Court has limited damages against nursing homes to $500 per lawsuit, a victory for the industry amid the coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: California Supreme Court Justice Mariano-Florentino Cuéllar, seen in January, wrote the 4-3 ruling that said a government agency's legal bills are generally public record in cases that have been resolved.

item.content:encoded: Jailhouse videos belie Joseph James DeAngelo Jr.'s appearances in court as a feeble, frail old man, prosecutors say.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this June 1, 2018, file, pool photo, Joseph James DeAngelo appears in Sacramento Superior Court, in Sacramento, Calif. Authorities have cleared DeAngelo accused of being California's Golden State Killer of involvement in the 1975 murder of a 14-year-old girl in the Central Valley. The Tulare County district attorney's office on Tuesday, Jan. 8, 2019, released a review that said DNA testing concluded that DeAngelo didn't kill Donna Jo Richmond. (Jose Luis Villegas/The Sacramento Bee via AP, Pool, File)

Newsom spoke about the state's response to novel coronavirus, also known as COVID-19. Behind him are Director of the Governor's Office of Emergency Services Mark Ghilarducci, right, and California Department of Public Health Director and State Health Officer Dr. Sonia Angell. Yesterday, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed a possible first case of person-to-person transmission of COVID-19 in California in the general public.(AP Photo/Randall Benton)

item.title: These nurses work in a hospital 'hot zone.' The virus stalks them as they return home

item.content:encoded: The AP followed four nurses working in the coronavirus unit at St. Jude's Medical Center in Fullerton. Nurses fear for their families after their shifts end.

media:content.media:description: Romelia Navarro, right, is comforted by nurse Michele Younkin as she weeps while sitting at the bedside of her dying husband, Antonio, in St. Jude Medical Center's COVID-19 unit in Fullerton, Calif., Friday, July 31, 2020. Antonio was Younkin's first COVID-19 patient to pass on her watch. (AP Photo/Jae C. Hong)

item.title: Admissions scandal: Prosecutors want 2 months in prison for Lori Loughlin, 5 months for husband

item.content:encoded: College admissions scandal prosecutors recommend Lori Loughlin and J. Mossimo Giannulli be sentenced to two and five months, respectively, in prison.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this April 3, 2019 file photo, actress Lori Loughlin, front, and husband, clothing designer Mossimo Giannulli, left, depart federal court in Boston after facing charges in a nationwide college admissions bribery scandal. Loughlin and her husband Giannulli said in court documents Monday, April 15, 2019, that they are pleading not guilty to charges that they took part in a sweeping college admissions bribery scam. (AP Photo/Steven Senne, File)

item.content:encoded: L.A. schools have launched a massive COVID-19 testing program in hopes of reopening campuses.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 07: Los Angeles Unified School District staff member Adrian Pacheco demonstrates the use of sanitizing tools as LAUSD Superintendent Austin Beutner takes a tour of Burbank Middle School with Principal Christine Moore on Friday, Aug. 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As the academic school year looms, preparations have been under way to make campuses safe inside and out, even though the school year will start with distance-learning only because of the surging coronavirus pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California power grid manager urges residents to conserve energy amid intense heat wave
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: The heat "is causing a strain on supplies, and consumers should be prepared for likely rolling outages during the late afternoons and early evenings through Wednesday," the California Independent System Operator said in its statewide flex alert Sunday.
item.content:encoded: The heat "is causing a strain on supplies, and consumers should be prepared for likely rolling outages during the late afternoons and early evenings through Wednesday," the California Independent System Operator said in its statewide flex alert Sunday.

media:content.media:description: A jogger runs in extreme heat under high tension electrical lines in the North Hollywood section of Los Angeles on Saturday, Aug. 15, 2020. California has ordered rolling power outages for the first time since 2001 as a statewide heat wave strained its electrical system. (AP Photo/Richard Vogel)

item.title: Reporting backlog continues to affect L.A. County COVID-19 case numbers
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 1,192 new cases of the coronavirus and nine related deaths but said both numbers were artificially low due to a weekend reporting lag.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 1,192 new cases of the coronavirus and nine related deaths but said both numbers were artificially low due to a weekend reporting lag.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - AUGUST 12, 2020 - -Richard Hernandes, from right to left, his girlfriend Jazmin Domingo, his brothers Seth Patlan, 5, and Joseph Hamassian, heed the, "Masks Up, Surf City," banner campaign to prevent coronavirus on Main Street in Huntington Beach on August 12, 2020. The campaign, a play on the phrase "Surf's Up," includes 100 pennants, a banner at the pier and digital displays citywide, Huntington Beach spokeswoman Catherine Jun said. Fifty pennants were installed downtown on Aug. 6. The remaining signs are in production this week, and 13 pennants and a banner are expected to be installed on the Huntington Beach Pier. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Massive wildfire spawns fire tornadoes in Northern California
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Videos posted to social media showed twister-like formations in the path of the Loyalton fire, which started Friday evening in the Tahoe National Forest.
item.content:encoded: Videos posted to social media showed twister-like formations in the path of the Loyalton fire, which started Friday evening in the Tahoe National Forest.

media:content.media:description: A funnel appears in a thick plume of smoke from the Loyalton Fire in Lassen County, Calif., on Saturday.

item.title: Los Angeles County church appears ready to defy court order and hold indoor services
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: Late Saturday, an appellate court set aside a lower court order to allow indoor services at Grace Community Church. But services are set to take place as usual.
item.content:encoded: Late Saturday, an appellate court set aside a lower court order to allow indoor services at Grace Community Church. But services are set to take place as usual.

item.title: Federal judge orders COVID-19 testing at Bakersfield immigration detention facility

item.content:encoded: Judge orders COVID-19 testing at Bakersfield immigration detention center where a spreading outbreak was met with 'deliberate indifference' for weeks.

item.title: Column One: Nearly half a century ago, activists 'invaded' this California island by claiming it for Mexico
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: In 1972, the mission of the Brown Berets was to occupy Catalina Island — land they believed belonged to Mexico. Nearly 48 years later, Chicano leader David Sanchez revisits the island and the legacy of the Berets' three-week occupation.
item.content:encoded: In 1972, the mission of the Brown Berets was to occupy Catalina Island — land they believed belonged to Mexico. Nearly 48 years later, Chicano leader David Sanchez revisits the island and the legacy of the Berets' three-week occupation.

media:content.media:description: CATALINA ISLAND, CA - AUGUST 07: Activist David Sanchez, of Huntington Park, who led the Brown Berets during the occupational protest in Catalina Island in 1972 as part of the Chicano Moratorium, revisit the point where he once protested in Avalon Friday, Aug. 7, 2020 in Catalina Island. The group of 26 planted a large Mexican flag on the point, referred to as Burrito Point by some locals, above the Chimes Tower and claimed the island in the name of Mexico. The Brown Berets are a pro-Chicano organization that emerged during the Chicano Movement in the late1960s to address the issues of educational reform, farm workers' rights, police brutality, anti-war activities and other problems confronting the Chicano community and was founded by Sanchez. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus complicates California's worst power shortage in two decades
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Jack Dolan
item.description: People staying home with air conditioners blasting, plus a dearth of power from other states results in the worst statewide energy shortage in nearly 20 years
item.content:encoded: People staying home with air conditioners blasting, plus a dearth of power from other states results in the worst statewide energy shortage in nearly 20 years

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA - AUGUST 18, 2020: Jon Galapago of Riverside wipes the sweat from his face while sitting in a hammock fishing at Lake Evans in triple digit temperatures on August 18, 2020 in Riverside, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Agent of colonialism' or a 'saint for our times'? Junipero Serra's legacy divides Latinos
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: Latinos have served as the most vocal detractors and defenders of Junípero Serra over the last few months in a fierce debate about the saint's legacy.
item.content:encoded: Latinos have served as the most vocal detractors and defenders of Junípero Serra over the last few months in a fierce debate about the saint's legacy.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - AUGUST 01: Veronica Valadez, 46, stands for a portrait where a statue of Fr. Juniper Serra once stood in front of Ventura city hall on Saturday, Aug. 1, 2020 in Ventura, CA. Valadez is one of several Latino detractors of Fr. Junipero Serra and believes the saint's work to convert local indigenous groups and build the California Mission system was oppressive, destructive of local cultures and led to many deaths of indigenous peoples. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Los Angeles County reports more than 2,100 new coronavirus cases and 35 more related deaths
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: The new numbers brought the county's totals to 220,762 positive cases of COVID-19 and 5,245 deaths. Saturday's death total was the lowest of any day this week.
item.content:encoded: The new numbers brought the county's totals to 220,762 positive cases of COVID-19 and 5,245 deaths. Saturday's death total was the lowest of any day this week.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08: EMT Hannah Mikus, right, demonstrates how to self administer the test to drivers during Coronavirus Covid-19 testing in LA County at the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science in South Los Angeles on July 8, 2020 as California records its highest single-day coronavirus death toll with 149 fatalities reported. The Charles R. Drew University site has tested a large number of people from racial and ethnic minority groups that are at higher risk for poor outcomes and complications from COVID-19. Drew University on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Lake and Ranch 2 fires burn thousands of acres as region is gripped in epic heat wave

item.title: State's freeze of COVID-19 watchlist magnifies breakdown in communication to counties
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The state's coronavirus watchlist, which guides its decision to allow counties to open certain sectors, including schools and in-person worship, was frozen last week after state officials announced that a test result backlog had led to an inaccurate case count.
item.content:encoded: The state's coronavirus watchlist, which guides its decision to allow counties to open certain sectors, including schools and in-person worship, was frozen last week after state officials announced that a test result backlog had led to an inaccurate case count.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - AUGUST 12, 2020 - - A couple walk past a sign that reads, "Please Wear Mask," in front of Dash of Sass clothing store along Main Street during a "Masks Up, Surf City," banner campaign to prevent coronavirus in the city of Huntington Beach on August 12, 2020. Customers are not allowed into the store unless they are wearing a mask. The campaign, a play on the phrase "Surf's Up," includes 100 pennants, a banner at the pier and digital displays citywide, Huntington Beach spokeswoman Catherine Jun said. Fifty pennants were installed downtown on Aug. 6. The remaining signs are in production this week, and 13 pennants and a banner are expected to be installed on the Huntington Beach Pier. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Lopez: A pandemic road trip isn't for cowards. Things to know before you go

item.description: The rest stop was another 60 miles up the road, which seemed as far off as a reliable vaccine, but I made it in the nick of time.

item.title: Long Beach mayor loses mother, stepfather to COVID weeks apart. He wants people to learn from it

item.description: "The days go pretty late" for Mayor Robert Garcia, who must guide Long Beach through a global health crisis while mourning two family members.
item.content:encoded: "The days go pretty late" for Mayor Robert Garcia, who must guide Long Beach through a global health crisis while mourning two family members.

media:content.media:description: Long Beach mayor Robert Garcia (right) holds his mother's hand during her wedding as Greg O'Donnell's mother holds his. Gaby and Greg O'Donnell both died due to complications from COVID-19.

item.title: Column: I wasn't a fan of Kamala Harris. It took President Trump to change my mind
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: Many Black progressives weren't fans of Kamala Harris. But President Trump's racist attacks have proved exactly why supporting her is necessary.
item.content:encoded: Many Black progressives weren't fans of Kamala Harris. But President Trump's racist attacks have proved exactly why supporting her is necessary.

media:content.media:description: Democratic presidential candidate former Vice President Joe Biden listens as his running mate Sen. Kamala Harris, D-Calif., speaks during a campaign event at Alexis Dupont High School in Wilmington, Del., Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020. (AP Photo/Carolyn Kaster)
